body.p: Gary O’Donovan,1 Jenyfer Tabares García,2 Diana Brunal Berrocal2 and Nelson Gaviria García2
1Facultad de Medicina, Universidad de los Andes, Bogotá, Colombia; 2INDER Alcaldía de Medellín, Medellín, Colombia.
Correspondence: Dr Gary O’Donovan, Facultad de Medicina, Universidad de los Andes, Carrera 1, 18A-12, Bogotá, Colombia 111711. Email: g.odonovan@uniandes.edu.co

list-item.p: mMore than 27 traditional sports disciplines; aerobics classes, walking groups, daytime and night-time Ciclovías, and other physical activity interventions; recreational activities for groups aged 0-–5, 6-–12, 13-–17, 18-–28, 29-–59, and 60+ years of age.

· All of the 7seven best investments for physical activity are addressed. See Oonline supplementary figure 1Figure (a Spanish version is available online). See Figure 1.figure 1. (A Spanish version is available online: see online supplementary figure 1).)
INDER works alongside and oversees the education sector, the community sector, and other public and private bodies involved in the public policy of sport and recreation.
uUp to 850, 000 (34%) of 2.5 million inhabitants every month, including people of all ages, abilities and socioeconomic levels.
· What is special about this programme?
Participation is free! You can even borrow a bike, a tennis racquet, or whatever you might need to enjoy your chosen sport.
· Website, with Facebook, Twitter and Instagram:

caption.title: How Institute of Sport and Recreation (INDER) embraces all seven best investments for physical activity.

body.title: Background: the right to sport and exercise is enshrined in the constitution
body.p: The Institute of Sport and Recreation (INDER, according to its initials in Spanish) of Medellín in Colombia is the decentralizeddecentralised department of the mayor’s office that is responsible for promoting physical activity, sport and recreation. INDER was created in 1993 in response to the state’s new constitution of 1991, which stated in Article 52 that1 : ‘“The practice of sport… has as its goal the shaping of well-rounded people, protecting and enhancing their health.’” And, that: ‘“Sport and recreation are part of one’s education and are the subject of public funds. The right of all people to sport, recreation and the best use of their free time is recognised. The state will promote these activities and will inspect, monitor and control sport and recreation organisations, whose structure and ownership must be democratic.’1” The mission and vision of INDER areis still very much in keeping with the constitution: to promote physical activity, sport and recreation through programmes and facilities that help shape well-rounded people, help improve quality of life, and help make Medellín a fairer, more inclusive and more tolerant city.2

INDER has grown from a workforce of 10 with a handful of volunteers to a workforce of around 2000 with an annual budget of around COP 85, 000, 000, 000 (around GBP 21, 000, 000). There has also been considerable investment in infrastructure with the hosting of major sporting events, such as the South American Games of 2010 and the FIFA Under-20 World Cup of 2011. More than 27 traditional sport and recreation activities are now offered to people of all ages, abilities and socioeconomic levels.3 Downhill, break dance, underwater rugby and other emerging trends in the region are also catered for.3 INDER operates more than 1000 sport and recreation facilities throughout Medellín, including the world-class facilities of the Unidad Deportiva Atanasio Girardot4 and the spectacular facilities of the Unidad Deportiva de Belén.5 A stretch of roads is closed to motor vehicles every Sunday morning and on public holidays in 13 different neighbourhoods so that people can enjoy walking, running, cycling or skating without traffic. The key feature of all the physical activity, sport and recreation programmes is that participation is entirely free.
body.title: INDER’Ss success
body.p: The WHO Global Action Plan on Physical Activity calls for investment in policies that promote physical activity, sport and exercise at a national scale,6 and INDER is a remarkable example of what can be achieved (see figure 1Figure). On average, the 65 kilometresm of closed roads of the Ciclovías attracts more than 100 000 participants every month (estimated from manual counts). Together, the Ciclovías and all the other physical activity, sport and recreation programmes attract as many as 850 000 (34%) of 2.5 million inhabitants of Medellín every month (the sum of manual counts and online bookings). Projects like Cultura del Fútbol (Football Culture) and Deporte, Convivencia y Paz (Sport, Living Together, and Peace) are indicative of the wider impact of sport on society. Success might also be expressed in terms of the legacy of major sports events. For example, more than 600 social houses and around 2500 jobs were created as a direct result of the South American Games of 2010.7 INDER is one of the most cherished institutions in Medellín,8 and air pollution is the only real threat because all of the physical activity, sport and recreation programmes are suspended when particulate matter concentrations are high.
body.title: Lessons learnedt
body.p: The recognition of the constitutional right to sport and exercise and decentralizationdecentralisation from central government have been key to the growth of INDER. Twenty-five5five years of experience haves culminated in a new strategy, Cultura D— – or Sports Culture.3 In order to make fairer, more transparent decisions, INDER has recently been restructured to include a Director, a Subdirector of Sport and Recreation Promotion, a Subdirector of Sports Centres, and a Subdirector of Administration and Finance.2 INDER has also devised models to make evidence-based decisions. For example, a prioritizationprioritisation model is now used to allocate new resources according to the size of the community, the socioeconomic status of the community, the existing sports facilities, and the current sports participation.3 One priority for the next fifteen15 years is to improve the existing sport and recreation facilities, rather than invest in more mega centres.3 Another priority, is to do more for the greater benefit of society.3 INDER has a greater presence in Medellín than any other department of the mayor’s office and programmes like Local Planning and Budget (PLyPP, according to its initials in Spanish) are likely to be extended so that more members of the community can work with INDER to decide how best to use physical activity, sport and recreation to help create the city that everyone dreams of.3

email-content.mail-subject: Proof of your article for British Journal of Sports Medicine - 10.1136/bjsports-2019-100907

mail-body.p: I’m pleased to provide the proof of your article, which is available on our author proofing system here:

Please submit any corrections then ensure you click ‘Approve’ to complete the author proofing process. Signing off the paper will send the article back to the Production team so they can make any changes.
Please note, the online author proofing system cannot be used in the browser Internet Explorer. Please review your proofs in Google Chrome.

A PDF version of the proof is available to download and review, but all corrections must be submitted using the online system. Please contact us at production.bjsm@bmj.com if you need any help using this.

This is the only opportunity you will have to correct your article before publication, so please review it carefully. Please ensure you respond to queries listed in the article. Minor errors cannot be corrected after publication and any serious scientific errors will result in a formal correction.
Reprints: If you wish to purchase reprints of your article, please fill in the reprint form.
British Journal of Sports Medicine Production Team
